pullrequest.title: Add clipping for depth camera on rgbd camera sensor

content.raw:
I got it working, the reason for the above problem seems to be that ogre only allows one clipping distance for the rgbd sensor so I had to do manual clipping in the Rgbd camera file

The one caveat to this workaround is that the assumption is made that the rgb far clipping will be greater than depth far clipping and rgb near clipping will be less than depth near clipping
content.html:
I got it working, the reason for the above problem seems to be that ogre only allows one clipping distance for the rgbd sensor so I had to do manual clipping in the Rgbd camera file

The one caveat to this workaround is that the assumption is made that the rgb far clipping will be greater than depth far clipping and rgb near clipping will be less than depth near clipping

content.raw:
> I’ve made <camera><depth_camera><clip> a required element that will be required if <depth_camera> is specified. Should this element be optional and if it exists, we simply prefer it over <camera><clip>?

Yeah, that sounds good to me.

> Additionally, how can I check to see if <depth_camera> or its respective clip values exists?

We can add `HasDepthCamera`, `HasDepthNearClip` and `HadDepthFarClip` to the `sdf::Camera` class? Also, consider renaming `NearDepthClip` to `DepthNearClip` and `FarDepthClip` -> `DepthFarClip` since the far/near clips are under depth.
content.html:
I’ve made <camera><depth_camera><clip> a required element that will be required if <depth_camera> is specified. Should this element be optional and if it exists, we simply prefer it over <camera><clip>?

Yeah, that sounds good to me.

Additionally, how can I check to see if <depth_camera> or its respective clip values exists?

We can add HasDepthCamera, HasDepthNearClip and HadDepthFarClip to the sdf::Camera class? Also, consider renaming NearDepthClip to DepthNearClip and FarDepthClip -> DepthFarClip since the far/near clips are under depth.

content.raw:
I’ve made `<camera><depth_camera><clip>` a required element that will be required if `<depth_camera>` is specified. Should this element be optional and if it exists, we simply prefer it over `<camera><clip>`?

Additionally, how can I check to see if `<depth_camera>` or its respective clip values exists?
content.html:
I’ve made <camera><depth_camera><clip> a required element that will be required if <depth_camera> is specified. Should this element be optional and if it exists, we simply prefer it over <camera><clip>?

Additionally, how can I check to see if <depth_camera> or its respective clip values exists?

pull_request.title: Add clipping for depth camera on rgbd camera sensor

pullrequest.title: Add clipping for depth camera on rgbd camera sensor

content.raw:
I'm not sure if we want to completely ignore `<camera><clip>`. My suggestion would be to use `<depth_camera><clip>`  only if `<depth_camera>` exists, otherwise, use `<camera><clip>`. This will maintain the current behavior, but allow users to set a separate clip parameter if they want to.

Also, if we ignore `<camera><clip>` for depth sensors, it can be confusing to debug for users if they forget to set `<camera><depth_camera><clip>` because the sensor will just pick up a default value and changing `<camera><clip>` won't make any difference. This is especially true for the depth-only sensor because users probably won't know that changing `<camera><clip>` won't affect anything without digging into the code.
content.html:
I'm not sure if we want to completely ignore <camera><clip>. My suggestion would be to use <depth_camera><clip> only if <depth_camera> exists, otherwise, use <camera><clip>. This will maintain the current behavior, but allow users to set a separate clip parameter if they want to.

Also, if we ignore <camera><clip> for depth sensors, it can be confusing to debug for users if they forget to set <camera><depth_camera><clip> because the sensor will just pick up a default value and changing <camera><clip> won't make any difference. This is especially true for the depth-only sensor because users probably won't know that changing <camera><clip> won't affect anything without digging into the code.
